Amazing game. A truly complete RPG.   One thing I've enjoyed most about RPG's such as Mass Effect, Elder Scrolls, Fall Out and so on is the dialogue. The depth of conversation options, how they effect encounters and the game itself, have always been one of my favorite parts of these games.   Dragon Age Origins is alike the games mentioned above in the aspects of dialogue and is one reason why I enjoyed it so much.   However it is also intertwined with one of the things I hate most about the game: the frequent crashes. There's nothing like going through an important piece of dialogue making numerous choices only to have the game crash in the fight that ensues.   While I am still looking into why the game crashes so much, I have a library of close to 60 games and this is the only title in my collection that I have any issues with. In a 4 hour session the game will crash anywhere from 1-3 times, I have 'gotten lucky' a few sessions and had zero issues. It is still frustrating to make progress, only to have to go over a conversation and handful of fights.   The issues with crashing almost made me not want to recommend the game. But for 7.50$ during the steam sale, I have to suggest you purchase this title. I can easily see myself putting 100+ hours into this game in the future.   If it weren't for the issues, I would easily recommend the game for it's full price of 30$.

When done with your beginning area you become a Gray Warden slayer of the Blight! And then you're game unravels with tons of side quests, A fun combat scheme. Unique characters, and so much more. Dragon Age is truly an exceptional fantasy RPG series that sets a very high standard with its first installment, Origins. Origins has a fluid storyline, a great deal of customization, and can appeal to gamers that like tactical strikes as well as those who prefer fluid combat (merely change your difficulty setting for one experience or the other). The game is partially open-world, rarely reuses scenery, and features fantastic voice acting, great characterization, the option to build significant relationships with companions, and a stunning soundtrack. The graphics are good for 2009, but pale in comparison to certain other RPG series (e.g. TES: Skyrim). Nevertheless, the game is easily modded, allowing both the nit-picky immersion player and the mod-happy player to customize their visual and game mechanic experience. (The DAO Nexus mod community is still active 5 years after the game's initial release.)  The Ultimate Edition contains all DLCs for DAO, as well as what could be considered Dragon Age 1.5, Awakening. Awakening allows the player to create a new character or to import their character from DAO and explore additional areas of Ferelden and well as further the DA storyline. Although DAO is primarily bug/glitch free, Awakening still has several bugs that Bioware failed to patch, so I recommend saving regularly in case you have to reload an area or questline. Despite this, however, Awakening continues Origins' compelling and engaging storyline and gameplay.  DAO is definitely a game worth playing once. Or again and again as most fans of the series do. As one would expect for a title like 'Origins', you can start the game in a number of unique ways, continously have different playthroughs, make many different decisions, and later import those decisions into Awakening and/or Dragon Age 2 to see the consequences of such actions (like fans of Bioware's Mass Effect series may be familiar with).  Additionally, Dragon Age: Inquistition will be released later this year (Fall 2014), so it's a great time to get into this series with a new installment on the way.

In addition there are major moral choices and sidings throughout, in preperation for the final battle as you seek to call on the signers of an ancient treaty you will face a dilemma in each situation. Do you (*SPOILERS*) instruct the werewolves to kill of the elvish? Or do you help the keeper end the curse he himself made by killing the werewolves? To gain the victor and potentially lose a companion. (*SPOILER END*) Each branch of quests across the continent are highly emotional and the characters themselves are highly believeable. I do love this game, but there is one part I dont like at all. In fact thats why I havent played in so long. It is the Fade. The dreamworld, where a demon places your whole party in a dream and you must use transformation to navigate the maze as a mouse, fire demon or spirit to free them with a confusing verbal slap to get them to muster themselves. It takes a couple hours, and in my opinion is not much fun.   But that is one minor part of one minor storyline that is otherwise brilliant (Mages revolt against their templars with bloodmagic, but Demons take their chance and break free, overwelming the tower as an army of abominations.) If you enjoyed Baldurs Gate, this combat system is the same. If you enjoy a good story, this game has them. If you love RPGs, classic and non, this is a must.

Dragon Age is must have for any RPG fans. Even in 2014 the graphics are still quite up to date if you ask me and the gameplay isn't all that hard to master. Dragon Age requires you to sit down for several hours and explore, talk to companions or strangers, travel the land and ofcourse slay the occasional dragon now and then. What I found suprising about this game is the depth of the characters that you meet troughout the game. The choices that you make (some of them are qutie difficult to make I might add) could have a strong effect on certain characters. Now that we start about choices.. choices.. CHOICES! The game is full of them, right from the very beginning. What will you be? A Mage? Warrior? Rogue? That doesn't even cover the class system, each class gets 4 specializations that can heavily impact the way that you can play. Even without the specializations there's plenty of different stlyes that you can use. For example as a Warrior you can go with; Sword and Shield, Duel-Wield, Two-Handed or Ranged. Each of these 4 different styles offer a different kind of gameplay. To get back on topic, the choices that you make not only impact your companions but they can also alter the world. One of the most important aspects of the game is the Combat System. Personally I just played on the easiest mode, rushed trough enemies without a proper strategy and let my companions sort themselves out. However, if you decide to play on a higher difficulty level you will need to pause the game and think of a proper way to deal with the enemies ahead.  So for those who like real time combat and for those who prefer to take their time and see a strategy work out fine, you'll both be happy with this game. I strongy recommend Dragon Age to people who play games such as The Witcher and The Elder Scrolls. I enjoyed evry minute I put into this game and I get the feeling I'll be playing it for a long time to come.
The best installment so far!

Among Bioware's many RPG titles, this game is one of the standouts in their considerable repertoire.  + Very well written and engaging storyline + Extremely well written and fleshed out characters + Tactical RPG combat that harkens back to Bioware's roots, in the era of Baldur's Gate and other older titles + Diverse character builds, especially for Mage + Good character modeling and decent textures for armor and weapons + Certain parts of the game's storyline are among the best gaming experiences I've had (***spoiler*** Deep Roads) + Satisfying climax + Very good voice acting and character dialogue + Ferelden is a well designed world that more resembles a medieval realm than other RPG games. + Good atmosphere, for the most part  - Graphics in general could be better, environmental textures especially - Character models are not very diverse, with perhaps a handful of facemaps and body skeletons for each race - Certain parts of the story can drag on a bit much - The Awakening DLC essentially makes the game a trivial affair in any difficulty besides Nightmare. - The other DLC aren't anything special, although they do tie up loose ends and provide some longevity to your character's story - Story does give the initial impression of being generic fantasy, at first.   Dragon Age Origins is a very well made game that stands among Bioware's best. A must play for any RPG fan.  91/100 Very strongly recommended

I forgot to play the post-game DLC before I uninstalled, the in-game DLC is essentially all win-more items, fetchquesting, and utility that is not in the main game but should be (like item storage). 2 side-characters, but nothing really interesting.  An okay game, but I've played better RPGs, ones more moving in their story and less refined in their mechanics.

I bought this game on a whim - hell it had dragons and that's pretty much a selling point for me.  When I started playing I discovered a unique and well-created world with engrossing, unique storylines, open-ended quests that could be done in any order (or in a specific order if you wanted a particular outcome, an easy to manage combat design, and, I save the best for last - the relationships.   Gradually growing closer to your companions is so much more realistic than stomping through exotic locations filled with hostile enemies with complete strangers at your side. Having your choices affect how your companions react to you, to each other and how your choices positively or negatively affect so many other aspects of the game is just a brilliant concept.   Character leveling gives you points to spend in various talent trees that are entirely up to you depending on how you prefer to play - you're not forced into any particular style of party. However, I do reccommend reading up some as it will reveal a lot of plot points, relationship issues and other random things you could miss out on if you don't have at least certain levels of some of the skills/talents.   It reminds a lot me of when I played old school D&D.  While the world is not as open as, say, Skyrim, it is still enough to keep you occupied for hours on end. For the RPGer who is looking for a new twist on an old genre - Dragon Age will not disappoint.

I give this game a recommendation with a huge asterisk*.  This game is TEDIOUS, in my opinion. It's essentially a hybrid of the style of gameplay of Neverwinter Nights 1 and Star Wars Nights of the Old Republic. While I enjoy those games, it can be a chore to plug through them. Dragon Age's combat is less interesting. I found combat breaks down into either auto-attacking or stunning. The more you can stun your enemies, the more powerful you are. This cycle of cutting down mobs is repetitive. Run into a room, aggro the mobs, stun stun stun, win. This is disappointing because of the number of unique character backstories that are available. I can tell that I won't have ambition to replay the game for this reason. This is just my opinion, but I recommend that you take a good look at the game before deciding if its for you.  Despite that, I was very engaged by this game. The story and characters are superb, just as you would expect from a Bioware title. I was propelled from the start to progress in the epic story. Your character feels as if he/she has substantial presence and impact in the world. Very much like Mass Effect in that regard. The game is also enormous, with many branching paths that each take hours to complete. You'll have plenty of content to enjoy. I would say this is Bioware's least polished recent game. I had several bugs and noticed multiple areas of poor or uninspired texturing. There is also frequent reuse of interior environments, such as dungeons and castles. I would have appreciated more visual diversity but given the already enormous 24GB size, I can understand why the developers needed to be conservative.  Overall its another strong title from Bioware, and is a fine reminder of their catalogue of older games.

There are few games that can be really called ART. Dragon Age is one of these.  I believe this is one of the first games which started the revolution to turn Videogames into something greater. The Gameplay is fun, never boring, with almost perfect statistics calculations, allowing the player a deep character customization. To level up is hard, but never boring, so that once you get a new upgrade, you feel excited to test the new strategy you can do. Through the in-combat pause strategy becomes fundamental, making every battle different, and exciting the player into making the perfect strategy, with his own style.  But as I said this game is more then mere gameplay.  It allows a deep role-play. The player can choose between several races, and origins, so to become the character he wants to.   But above all, the immersion. The story is deep, set in a living world, with its problems and its beauties, and it is in this world that the player will have to act, making important choises that will affect the future, sometimes choises so hard that the player is forced to think deeply about what is right and what evil, and even to grow. Even the world is profoundly inspired. It is not the usual fantasy, but . As great fantasy works of art, such as the Lord Of The Rings, it is deep, profound. I actually don't know how to describe this, but try to understand what I mean. In it we see the horrors of the life, despair and death, but in all this darkness, we even see beauty: heroes, great men and women, devoted to greatness and beauty. All of this affects the heart, which is perhaps the aim of the art. Altough the nature of the art is one of the most debated issues. As the player walks in the world, choosing his companions he knows them deeply, up to become attacched to them. The locations and even the artistic style is inspired.  This is a game, a World, made with passion and love, as few artistic works nowadays. Played 128 hours. Sorry for the mistakes with english, but I wanted the more people to be able to read this.

Loving this game so far. The graphics are a bit out-dated (I have all of them on the highest settings and it still doesn't look terribly good), but it is an older game, so I can forgive it. As a huge political intrigue/story nut, this game is my jam. I love how I'm talking to people just as much as I'm fighting. That being said, if you're the kind of person who skips through dialogue to get to the action, then you'll absolutely hate this game.   Even though the old Icewind Dale games were already considered old by the time I played them, I still got a whiff of nostalgia from this game, not a surprise considering that Bioware also made the Baldur's Gate series, and I loved how it mixed old strategy game tropes with some new, flashy ideas of it's own. Just made me really happy running around the world in tactical mode, remembering all of those times when I would force my friend (who owned the game) to run around in Icewind Dale II with me, having absolutely no idea what we were doing and generally making fools of ourselves. But those were good memories, so I can't complain.  Picked this game up in a sale, and glad I did (I was a little nervous that I wouldn't like it), but I now realize that if I'd known how awesome this game is I would've paid the full price without even thinking twice. If you're a fan of plot-heavy fantasy games, than this is the one for you!

Um well... The character creator is a little annoying. The first character I created was a real ugly mess. He looked fine in the character creator, but when I bring into the world and start comparing him to the character models I realise that he looks like he's come right out of The Planet of the Apes. I also created a Dalish Elf character. I had learnt my lesson. Don't fiddle too much with the character creator. This one looks good. But, oh wait, Dalish Elves all have facial tattoos. But not my character. Now how I have to play like someone with their own rules. Someone stubborn, and doesn't care for tradition to justify this lack of tatooness. Needless to say she is a racist. But she doesn't have a quirky portrait picture so she can't be any of these things because clearly she isn't a 'Character'. I think the reason I have never gotten on too well with proper RPG's is becoming very apparent. Good stuff.  Edit: I would probably get some hate from hardcore Dragon Age fans or even A Song of Ice and Fire fans but it really does have that Game of Thrones feel. I really do love that. I am fairly well researched on games. Certainly good series', and yet I hadn't given DA a go. I guess I got scared off by the acclaim of the second game. As an icredibly large fan of Mass Effect, and someone who really has developed a love affair with Bioware, I'll be continuing over on Origin.  Edit Edit: A big negative from this game is that it suffers a severe case of Bethesda Syndrome. If you don't save regularly it really makes you pay for it. I dislike that a lot, although, I don't believe it's anything new for Bioware. The first Mass Effect did it a lot too.  Edit Edit Edit: Seriously though!!! It's a big problem!

I'd never been much of an RPG fan until I played Dragon Age: Origins. Most of the games I'd played seemed to be overly complicated for complication's sake, but with Dragon Age, situations can get hairy, but if you take your time and have a little bit of forethought, you'll be rewarded. That's one of my favorite parts, besides the writing, depth of characters, story and vocal performance, I enjoy the most, the many different ways you can go about solving a problem. Each fight, you can be totally hands on, sit back and let your dps/tank/healer do their thing, or a combination of both. And I think that's part of the reason this game has been around and popular for so long, you can replay it with different classes and make different choices, something Bioware is excellent at. Your best value is to get this ultimate edition, because of how much is thrown in. The Awakening DLC is huge and a necessary bridge to Dragon Age II and Inquisition that fleshes out the world of Thedas that much more. Definitely give this game a shot, if you have the chance.

The story is pretty standard fare for dark fantasy, but the characters are super engaging and well-acted and the worldbuilding is top notch, with each region having its own distinct look. The plot is broken into several discrete units, each its own complete story that feels different from the others, while still feeling like an important contribution to the overall plot. And the Origins and story branching add tons of role-play replayability. Honestly it feels like the best paced game in the franchise so far.  Gameplay wise, tactical is great in this game. It feels natural on keyboard and confrontations are varied enough to keep things interesting. If you're on controller, or just don't like tactical play, I'd recommend keeping the game on a lower difficulty as some of the confrontations can get a bit tedious otherwise. Exploration is solid, though some event triggers are eternally bugged. I enjoy the class and skill system, even if it can be frustrating going through useless skills to get higher up ones.   Honestly all of its flaws, aside from game crashing and missed triggers, feel like part of the game's charm. It's not as big or open as Skyrim, but ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ if it doesn't look, sound, and feel better overall

I generally enjoyed playing this game, its strongest points being storyline and characters (both PC and NPC).  Pros: 1. There is a coherent storyline, with outcomes strongly contingent on in-game decisions. 2. Basic combat is fairly easy to master. 3. The characters are distinctive in temperament and ability, frequently amusing, and their reactions and behaviour are relevant to outcomes. 4. The game is fairly easy to mod, mostly through the DAO Modmanager, available on Nexus. 5. Commitment to one path of character specialization or another gives higher returns than attempting a generalist playstyle. 6. Replayability is pretty good, though ultimately you are still stuck with the linear narrative.  Cons: 1. Even by the standards of its release date the sets and artistry are nothing spectacular. 2. If you have my lazy playstyle, navigating the tactics menu (which is a powerful game tool and make battles flow smoothly) is difficult, tedious, and irritating. Failure to do so makes combat a process of pause, issue orders, unpause, assess, pause, issue new orders, repeat. 3. By the late game, the quests have become repetitious, and yet must be completed to advance the narrative. 4. As a linear (as opposed to open world) game, you must go to all lengths to acquire every scrap of loot and experience in order to acquire the best equipment and defeat the top adversaries.

Played more DAO than any other game except Civ5. Modding DAO is definitely a bit of work, but once I had all I wanted tweaked, the game was so immersive for me that there's no set of game characters I remember more fondly and was one of the few games I've completed start to finish repeatedly plus the DLC.  I still resist the notion of DAO being the 'spiritual successor to Baldur's Gate,' but after being a huge BG fan, then a huge NWN fan, this fit right in afterward despite it dropping DnD as a basis for the game mechanics (and Forgotten Realms as a setting, alas). DAO borrows from a lot of genre for inspiration- can take you through horror scenes to adventure encounters to tavern brawls to war scenes out of 'Braveheart' to completely tactical encounters where you're using every fraction of a second to pull through.  DA fans tend to guffaw at DAO's 'origin story' experience as 'just a tutorial,' but that's DAO's most endearing, immersive element for me, the initial investment in your character and his/her motivations that makes the rest of the game so worth exploring to the fullest with them. And not just the initial part but how things have changed when you return to the same origin location after becoming a Gray Warden (esp. the dwarf origins.) You will have a very unique experience with whatever race/background you choose, and the writers were very creative about how they introduce you to the DA lore and gameworld. It's the synergy between the attention to detail paid to your own character's story AND to the unfolding of the overall lore that's the biggest draw for me. Despite them dropping the ball in DA2 and DAI in terms of creative investment in your own character's story, the DAverse is by far the most interesting, engaging, and at times thought-provoking game setting I've encountered in any game regardless of genre or type.  If I had to criticize DAO I'd say the combat mechanics haven't aged that well. Like DnD it uses RNG in your to-hit chances (no dodge rolls or FPS aiming) which is fine really (XCOM uses it well), but the way it was implemented there is a lot of running in and watching your attack animation do diddlysquat while you get clobbered... at least until later in the game. So if anything don't prepare for a very robust combat system, even though the ability to control your full party is far better in DAO than DAI... The clunky combat is the primary reason I can't get into DAO any more, but that's not to say the combat's not enjoyable, esp. if you're new to the game anyway.  It's an old-style RPG- no spoken lines by your protagonist (though plenty of snarky, poignant, etc. lines to choose from), paused combat, less sophisticated cutscenes- but with a decidedly more mature narrative- both due to 'mature' content and to a more sophisticated social outlook. And it works. Well. It's a great example of a very intelligent, creative dev team that worked the frickin frack out of limited game resources to turn out something exceptional.
